update.description:
This is marked WIP because it needs new releases of SDF9 and ign-common3. We can't make those until after the Urban Circuit. 

This is a port of [Gazebo classic's buoyancy plugin](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/src/default/plugins/BuoyancyPlugin.hh). 

The behavior of this Buoyancy plugin matches that of Gazebo classic. The primary difference is that this new plugin can calculate the volume of meshes. The old plugin offered some more customization via plugin SDF elements. I left those out for now since I didn't have a good use case.

I could use some eyes on the math in `Buoyancy.cc`.
update.title: Buoyancy

update.title: [WIP] Buoyancy

content.raw:
I did this on purpose because:

1. Adding a buoyancy plugin to every model that needs to be buoyant is difficult to maintain and not scalable. We would have to duplicate each Fuel model that needs to function in and out of water. Or, we would have to add the plugins to each model via a launch file.
2. Adding a world property to a model plugin is not very intuitive, and it is a pattern that we should avoid. A model plugin should only pertain to the model itself, such as a robot controller. Environmental effects should be handled at the world level. There are probably corner cases, but I think it's a good rule of thumb to follow.
3. We don't have worlds that need to simulate both underwater and above water environments simultaneously. We may in the future, but planning for a hypothetical future is feature creep. There is a hook to adjust the fluid density based on the pose of the entity. When we encounter this scenario, then we can implement that hook. See  the `double BuoyancyPrivate::FluidDensity` function.
content.html:
I did this on purpose because:

  1. Adding a buoyancy plugin to every model that needs to be buoyant is difficult to maintain and not scalable. We would have to duplicate each Fuel model that needs to function in and out of water. Or, we would have to add the plugins to each model via a launch file.
  2. Adding a world property to a model plugin is not very intuitive, and it is a pattern that we should avoid. A model plugin should only pertain to the model itself, such as a robot controller. Environmental effects should be handled at the world level. There are probably corner cases, but I think it's a good rule of thumb to follow.
  3. We don't have worlds that need to simulate both underwater and above water environments simultaneously. We may in the future, but planning for a hypothetical future is feature creep. There is a hook to adjust the fluid density based on the pose of the entity. When we encounter this scenario, then we can implement that hook. See the double BuoyancyPrivate::FluidDensity function.

update.description:
This is marked WIP because it needs new releases of SDF9 and ign-common3. We can't make those until after the Urban Circuit. 

This is a port of [Gazebo classic's buoyancy plugin](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/src/default/plugins/BuoyancyPlugin.hh). 

The behavior of this Buoyancy plugin matches that of Gazebo classic. The primary difference is that this new plugin can calculate the volume of meshes. The old plugin offered some more customization via plugin SDF elements. I left those out for now since I didn't have a good use case.

I could use some eyes on the math in `Buoyancy.cc`.
update.title: [WIP] Buoyancy

content.raw: I did a first pass and it works for me. I didn't check the math too deeply.
content.html: I did a first pass and it works for me. I didn't check the math too deeply.

content.raw:
Some other things that may be worth testing:

* A mesh geometry
* A link with a center of volume different from the center of mass
* Check that the `CenterOfVolume` and `Volume` components are created and contain the correct data
content.html:
Some other things that may be worth testing:

  • A mesh geometry
  • A link with a center of volume different from the center of mass
  • Check that the CenterOfVolume and Volume components are created and contain the correct data

content.raw: Thinking of the future when there's support for more complex fluid densities, how do you think this element could change? Maybe this could be something like `uniform_fluid_density` to differentiate it from other options to come?
content.html: Thinking of the future when there's support for more complex fluid densities, how do you think this element could change? Maybe this could be something like uniform_fluid_density to differentiate it from other options to come?

content.raw: Implementing this as a world plugin that affects all models in the world could make it difficult to use it with worlds that have both underwater and land models. Have you given any thought to this use case?
content.html: Implementing this as a world plugin that affects all models in the world could make it difficult to use it with worlds that have both underwater and land models. Have you given any thought to this use case?

content.raw: I can imagine this warning being a bit spammy for users who want to have planes in their worlds and are ok with the plane being ignored by buoyancy. Consider making it into `ignmsg` or `igndbg`
content.html: I can imagine this warning being a bit spammy for users who want to have planes in their worlds and are ok with the plane being ignored by buoyancy. Consider making it into ignmsg or igndbg

content.raw: It could be a bit dangerous to store a pointer to a component. You'd have to be careful that the component has not been removed by another system, you shouldn't change it during `PostUpdate`, etc.
content.html: It could be a bit dangerous to store a pointer to a component. You'd have to be careful that the component has not been removed by another system, you shouldn't change it during PostUpdate, etc.

content.raw: Did you mean to change this world? Since it's a released version and the worlds are installed, how about creating a new world?
content.html: Did you mean to change this world? Since it's a released version and the worlds are installed, how about creating a new world?
